--- title: "Data wrangling 2" author: "Claus O. Wilke" date: last-modified format: revealjs: theme: - default - Wilke-theme.scss auto-stretch: false chalkboard: true execute: fig-format: svg fig-asp: 0.618 fig-width: 5.5 --- ## Elementary data manipulations :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} Previous class: - Pick rows: `filter()` - Pick columns: `select()` - Sort rows: `arrange()` - Count things: `count()` - Make new columns: `mutate()` ::: ::: {.fragment .column width="50%"} This class: ::: {.incremental} - Analyze subsets:
`group_by()` and `summarize()` - Reshape:
`pivot_wider()`, `pivot_longer()` - Combine datasets:
`left_join()`, `inner_join()`, `...` ::: ::: :::: ## Analyze subsets: `group_by()` and `summarize()` ::: {.move-down-2em} ![](../assets/data-wrangling-2/summarize.svg){fig-align="center" width="90%"} ::: ## Example application of grouping: Counting Previously, we counted like so: ::: {.small-font} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(palmerpenguins) # loads the `penguins` dataset penguins |> count(species) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 3 × 2 species n 1 Adelie 152 2 Chinstrap 68 3 Gentoo 124 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.fragment} Now let's do it the hard way . . . ::: ## Example application of grouping: Counting Let's go back to the raw data: ::: {.small-font} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} penguins ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 344 × 8 species island bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_length_mm body_mass_g 1 Adelie Torgersen 39.1 18.7 181 3750 2 Adelie Torgersen 39.5 17.4 186 3800 3 Adelie Torgersen 40.3 18 195 3250 4 Adelie Torgersen NA NA NA NA 5 Adelie Torgersen 36.7 19.3 193 3450 6 Adelie Torgersen 39.3 20.6 190 3650 7 Adelie Torgersen 38.9 17.8 181 3625 8 Adelie Torgersen 39.2 19.6 195 4675 9 Adelie Torgersen 34.1 18.1 193 3475 10 Adelie Torgersen 42 20.2 190 4250 # ℹ 334 more rows # ℹ 2 more variables: sex , year ``` ::: ::: ::: ## Example application of grouping: Counting Let's group it: ::: {.small-font} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} penguins |> group_by(species) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 344 × 8 # Groups: species [3] species island bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_length_mm body_mass_g 1 Adelie Torgersen 39.1 18.7 181 3750 2 Adelie Torgersen 39.5 17.4 186 3800 3 Adelie Torgersen 40.3 18 195 3250 4 Adelie Torgersen NA NA NA NA 5 Adelie Torgersen 36.7 19.3 193 3450 6 Adelie Torgersen 39.3 20.6 190 3650 7 Adelie Torgersen 38.9 17.8 181 3625 8 Adelie Torgersen 39.2 19.6 195 4675 9 Adelie Torgersen 34.1 18.1 193 3475 10 Adelie Torgersen 42 20.2 190 4250 # ℹ 334 more rows # ℹ 2 more variables: sex , year ``` ::: ::: ::: ## Example application of grouping: Counting And summarize: ::: {.small-font} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} penguins |> group_by(species) |> summarize( n = n() # n() returns the number of observations per group ) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 3 × 2 species n 1 Adelie 152 2 Chinstrap 68 3 Gentoo 124 ``` ::: ::: ::: ## Example application of grouping: Counting Now let's group by multiple variables: ::: {.small-font} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} penguins |> group_by(species, island) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 344 × 8 # Groups: species, island [5] species island bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_length_mm body_mass_g 1 Adelie Torgersen 39.1 18.7 181 3750 2 Adelie Torgersen 39.5 17.4 186 3800 3 Adelie Torgersen 40.3 18 195 3250 4 Adelie Torgersen NA NA NA NA 5 Adelie Torgersen 36.7 19.3 193 3450 6 Adelie Torgersen 39.3 20.6 190 3650 7 Adelie Torgersen 38.9 17.8 181 3625 8 Adelie Torgersen 39.2 19.6 195 4675 9 Adelie Torgersen 34.1 18.1 193 3475 10 Adelie Torgersen 42 20.2 190 4250 # ℹ 334 more rows # ℹ 2 more variables: sex , year ``` ::: ::: ::: ## Example application of grouping: Counting And summarize: ::: {.small-font} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} penguins |> group_by(species, island) |> summarize( n = n() # n() returns the number of observations per group ) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 5 × 3 # Groups: species [3] species island n 1 Adelie Biscoe 44 2 Adelie Dream 56 3 Adelie Torgersen 52 4 Chinstrap Dream 68 5 Gentoo Biscoe 124 ``` ::: ::: ::: ## Example application of grouping: Counting `count(...)` is a short-cut for:
`group_by(...) |> summarize(n = n())` :::: {.columns} ::: {.fragment .column width="50%" .small-font} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # penguins |> count(species) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 3 × 2 species n 1 Adelie 152 2 Chinstrap 68 3 Gentoo 124 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.fragment .column width="50%" .small-font} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} penguins |> group_by(species) |> summarize(n = n()) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 3 × 2 species n 1 Adelie 152 2 Chinstrap 68 3 Gentoo 124 ``` ::: ::: ::: :::: ::: {.fragment} The output is exactly the same ::: ## Performing multiple summaries at once ::: {.fragment .small-font} ::: {.cell output-location='fragment'} ```{.r .cell-code} penguins |> group_by(species) |> summarize( n = n(), # number of penguins mean_mass = mean(body_mass_g), # mean body mass max_flipper_length = max(flipper_length_mm), # max flipper length percent_female = sum(sex == "female")/n() # percent of female penguins ) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 3 × 5 species n mean_mass max_flipper_length percent_female 1 Adelie 152 NA NA NA 2 Chinstrap 68 3733. 212 0.5 3 Gentoo 124 NA NA NA ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.fragment} Each statement in `summarize()` creates one new column ::: ::: {.fragment} But why all the `NA`s? ::: ## Performing multiple summaries at once ::: {.small-font} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} penguins |> group_by(species) |> summarize( n = n(), mean_mass = mean(body_mass_g, na.rm = TRUE), max_flipper_length = max(flipper_length_mm, na.rm = TRUE), percent_female = sum(sex == "female", na.rm = TRUE)/sum(!is.na(sex)) ) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 3 × 5 species n mean_mass max_flipper_length percent_female 1 Adelie 152 3701. 210 0.5 2 Chinstrap 68 3733. 212 0.5 3 Gentoo 124 5076. 231 0.487 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.fragment} We typically need to tell R how exactly `NA`s should be handled ::: # Reshaping: Making tables wider or longer ## Reshape: `pivot_wider()` and `pivot_longer()` ::: {.move-down-1em} ![](../assets/data-wrangling-2/pivot.svg){fig-align="center" width="50%"} ::: ## Reshaping example: Making a wide summary table ::: {.small-font} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} penguins |> count(species, island) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 5 × 3 species island n 1 Adelie Biscoe 44 2 Adelie Dream 56 3 Adelie Torgersen 52 4 Chinstrap Dream 68 5 Gentoo Biscoe 124 ``` ::: ::: ::: ## Reshaping example: Making a wide summary table ::: {.small-font} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} penguins |> count(species, island) |> pivot_wider(names_from = "island", values_from = "n") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 3 × 4 species Biscoe Dream Torgersen 1 Adelie 44 56 52 2 Chinstrap NA 68 NA 3 Gentoo 124 NA NA ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.fragment} The `NA`s indicate cases that don't exist ::: ## And going back to long format ::: {.small-font} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} penguins_wide <- penguins |> count(species, island) |> pivot_wider(names_from = "island", values_from = "n") penguins_wide |> pivot_longer(cols = -species, names_to = "island", values_to = "n") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 9 × 3 species island n 1 Adelie Biscoe 44 2 Adelie Dream 56 3 Adelie Torgersen 52 4 Chinstrap Biscoe NA 5 Chinstrap Dream 68 6 Chinstrap Torgersen NA 7 Gentoo Biscoe 124 8 Gentoo Dream NA 9 Gentoo Torgersen NA ``` ::: ::: ::: ## And going back to long format Column specifications work just like in `select()`: ::: {.small-font} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # specify columns by subtraction penguins_wide |> pivot_longer(cols = -species, names_to = "island", values_to = "n") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 9 × 3 species island n 1 Adelie Biscoe 44 2 Adelie Dream 56 3 Adelie Torgersen 52 4 Chinstrap Biscoe NA 5 Chinstrap Dream 68 6 Chinstrap Torgersen NA 7 Gentoo Biscoe 124 8 Gentoo Dream NA 9 Gentoo Torgersen NA ``` ::: ::: ::: ## And going back to long format Column specifications work just like in `select()`: ::: {.small-font} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # specify columns by explicit listing penguins_wide |> pivot_longer(cols = c(Biscoe, Dream, Torgersen), names_to = "island", values_to = "n") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 9 × 3 species island n 1 Adelie Biscoe 44 2 Adelie Dream 56 3 Adelie Torgersen 52 4 Chinstrap Biscoe NA 5 Chinstrap Dream 68 6 Chinstrap Torgersen NA 7 Gentoo Biscoe 124 8 Gentoo Dream NA 9 Gentoo Torgersen NA ``` ::: ::: ::: ## And going back to long format Column specifications work just like in `select()`: ::: {.small-font} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # specify columns by range penguins_wide |> pivot_longer(cols = Biscoe:Torgersen, names_to = "island", values_to = "n") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 9 × 3 species island n 1 Adelie Biscoe 44 2 Adelie Dream 56 3 Adelie Torgersen 52 4 Chinstrap Biscoe NA 5 Chinstrap Dream 68 6 Chinstrap Torgersen NA 7 Gentoo Biscoe 124 8 Gentoo Dream NA 9 Gentoo Torgersen NA ``` ::: ::: ::: # Combining datasets: joins ## We use joins to add columns from one table into another ::: {.move-down-2em} ![](../assets/data-wrangling-2/join.svg){fig-align="center" width="75%"} ::: ## Example: band members and their instruments :::: {.columns} ::: {.fragment .small-font .column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # some members of famous bands band_members ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 3 × 2 name band 1 Mick Stones 2 John Beatles 3 Paul Beatles ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.fragment .small-font .column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # instruments played band_instruments ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 3 × 2 name plays 1 John guitar 2 Paul bass 3 Keith guitar ``` ::: ::: ::: ::::
::: {.fragment .small-font} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # add right table to left left_join(band_members, band_instruments) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 3 × 3 name band plays 1 Mick Stones 2 John Beatles guitar 3 Paul Beatles bass ``` ::: ::: ::: ## Example: band members and their instruments :::: {.columns} ::: {.small-font .column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # some members of famous bands band_members ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 3 × 2 name band 1 Mick Stones 2 John Beatles 3 Paul Beatles ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.small-font .column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # instruments played band_instruments ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 3 × 2 name plays 1 John guitar 2 Paul bass 3 Keith guitar ``` ::: ::: ::: ::::
::: {.small-font} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # add left table to right right_join(band_members, band_instruments) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 3 × 3 name band plays 1 John Beatles guitar 2 Paul Beatles bass 3 Keith guitar ``` ::: ::: ::: ## Example: band members and their instruments :::: {.columns} ::: {.small-font .column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # some members of famous bands band_members ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 3 × 2 name band 1 Mick Stones 2 John Beatles 3 Paul Beatles ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.small-font .column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # instruments played band_instruments ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 3 × 2 name plays 1 John guitar 2 Paul bass 3 Keith guitar ``` ::: ::: ::: ::::
::: {.small-font} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # keep intersection only inner_join(band_members, band_instruments) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 2 × 3 name band plays 1 John Beatles guitar 2 Paul Beatles bass ``` ::: ::: ::: ## Example: band members and their instruments :::: {.columns} ::: {.small-font .column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # some members of famous bands band_members ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 3 × 2 name band 1 Mick Stones 2 John Beatles 3 Paul Beatles ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.small-font .column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # instruments played band_instruments ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 3 × 2 name plays 1 John guitar 2 Paul bass 3 Keith guitar ``` ::: ::: ::: ::::
::: {.small-font} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # merge all cases full_join(band_members, band_instruments) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 4 × 3 name band plays 1 Mick Stones 2 John Beatles guitar 3 Paul Beatles bass 4 Keith guitar ``` ::: ::: ::: ## The different joins at a glance ::: {.move-down-2em} ![](../assets/data-wrangling-2/joins-venn.svg){fig-align="center" width="65%"} ::: ## The different joins at a glance ![](../assets/data-wrangling-2/joins-venn.svg){.absolute top="0%" left="65%" width="35%"}
:::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="65%"} **Tip:** In case of doubt, use `left_join()` ::: {.fragment} In my experience, `left_join()` is the right choice 70–80% of the time ::: ::: :::: ## Further reading - R for Data Science: [Chapter 5.6: Grouped summaries with `summarise()`](https://r4ds.had.co.nz/transform.html?q=group_by#grouped-summaries-with-summarise) - R for Data Science: [Chapter 12.3: Pivoting](https://r4ds.had.co.nz/tidy-data.html?q=pivot#pivoting) - R for Data Science: [Chapter 13: Relational data](https://r4ds.had.co.nz/relational-data.html) - **dplyr** documentation: [Grouped data](https://dplyr.tidyverse.org/articles/grouping.html) - **tidyr** documentation: [Pivoting](https://tidyr.tidyverse.org/articles/pivot.html) - **dplyr** documentation: [Mutating joins](https://dplyr.tidyverse.org/articles/two-table.html#mutating-joins-1)

include-after-body:
<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
